title: Job Chapter 18 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Job chapter 18 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Job Chapter 18 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Job Chapter 18.

questions.question: Who answered Job in Job Chapter 18?
questions.correctAnswer: Bildad the Shuhite
questions.explanation: Job 18:1 states, 'Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said,' identifying Bildad as the speaker.

questions.question: In Job 18:2, what does Bildad ask Job about their conversation?
options: How long will you continue speaking?
questions.correctAnswer: How long will you continue speaking?
questions.explanation: Job 18:2 says, 'How long will it be ere ye make an end of words?' showing Bildad's question about the length of Job's speech.

questions.question: According to Job 18:5, what will happen to the light of the wicked?
options: It shall be given to the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be put out
questions.explanation: Job 18:5 states, 'Yea, the light of the wicked shall be put out,' indicating the extinguishing of the wicked's light.

questions.question: What does Job 18:6 say about the wicked's candle?
options: It shall be put out with him
It will flicker but not burn
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be put out with him
questions.explanation: Job 18:6 says, 'his candle shall be put out with him,' meaning the wicked's light will go out upon his death.

questions.question: True or False: Job 18:8 describes the wicked as being caught in a net by their own feet.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 18:8 states, 'For he is cast into a net by his own feet,' confirming the statement is true.

questions.question: According to Job 18:10, where is the snare laid for the wicked?
options: In the ground and in the way
In the trees and on the mountain
In the city and the temple
In the sea and on the shore
questions.correctAnswer: In the ground and in the way
questions.explanation: Job 18:10 says, 'The snare is laid for him in the ground, and a trap for him in the way,' describing the locations of the snare.

questions.question: What causes the wicked to be afraid on every side in Job 18:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Terrors
questions.explanation: Job 18:11 states, 'Terrors shall make him afraid on every side,' identifying terrors as the cause of fear.

questions.question: True or False: Job 18:14 says the wicked's confidence will remain strong in his tabernacle.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 18:14 says, 'His confidence shall be rooted out of his tabernacle,' so the confidence does not remain strong.

questions.question: What will happen to the wicked's roots according to Job 18:16?
options: They shall be dried up beneath
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be dried up beneath
questions.explanation: Job 18:16 states, 'His roots shall be dried up beneath,' describing the fate of the wicked's roots.

questions.question: According to Job 18:17, what will happen to the wicked's remembrance on earth?
questions.correctAnswer: It shall perish
questions.explanation: Job 18:17 says, 'His remembrance shall perish from the earth,' showing the wicked will be forgotten.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the wicked's fate in Job 18:18?
questions.correctAnswer: Driven from light into darkness
questions.explanation: Job 18:18 states, 'He shall be driven from light into darkness,' describing the wicked's fate.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Job 18:19: 'He shall neither have son nor ______ among his people.'
questions.correctAnswer: nephew
questions.explanation: Job 18:19 says, 'He shall neither have son nor nephew among his people,' filling the blank with nephew.

questions.question: What shall those who come after the wicked do on his day, according to Job 18:20?
questions.correctAnswer: Be astonished
questions.explanation: Job 18:20 says, 'They that come after him shall be astonied at his day,' meaning they will be astonished.

questions.question: True or False: Job 18:21 says the place of the wicked is for those who know God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 18:21 states, 'this is the place of him that knoweth not God,' indicating it is not for those who know God.

questions.question: According to Job 18:13, what shall devour the strength of the wicked's skin?
questions.correctAnswer: The firstborn of death
questions.explanation: Job 18:13 says, 'the firstborn of death shall devour his strength,' identifying what devours the strength.

medium.title: Job Chapter 18 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Job Chapter 18 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Job 18, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in adversity?
options: The wicked will lose their light and strength, showing the importance of obedience to God.
Earth will be forsaken for the righteous, so they need not worry.
God removes the rock from its place for the faithful.
Anger is a sign of true faith during trials.
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked will lose their light and strength, showing the importance of obedience to God.
questions.explanation: Job 18:5-7 teaches that the light of the wicked will be put out and their strength will be diminished, emphasizing the consequence of disobedience and the need for faithfulness. This encourages believers to trust God and remain obedient through trials.

questions.question: How does Job 18:3-4 instruct believers about humility when others perceive them poorly?
options: Believers should not be angry or feel forsaken even if others count them as beasts or vile.
Believers must respond with harsh words to defend their reputation.
They should remove themselves from fellowship.
God will always remove the rock for their sake.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should not be angry or feel forsaken even if others count them as beasts or vile.
questions.explanation: Job 18:3-4 shows Bildad challenging Job's anger and questioning whether the earth will be forsaken for him, teaching believers to remain humble and not be consumed by anger when misunderstood.

questions.question: When faced with temptation and consequences of sin, what lesson does Job 18:8-10 convey about personal responsibility?
options: The wicked are caught by their own feet and walk into snares they set themselves.
God always saves the wicked from traps.
Temptation has no consequences if one prays enough.
Others are responsible for our traps and snares.
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked are caught by their own feet and walk into snares they set themselves.
questions.explanation: Job 18:8-10 describes how the wicked are ensnared by their own actions, highlighting the importance of personal responsibility and avoiding sin.

questions.question: A believer struggling with fear asks what biblical truth about God’s justice can be found in Job 18:11-13?
options: Terrors and destruction await the wicked, showing that God’s justice is sure and fearsome.
Fear is not real and should be ignored.
God protects the wicked from destruction.
The firstborn of death is mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: Terrors and destruction await the wicked, showing that God’s justice is sure and fearsome.
questions.explanation: Job 18:11-13 reveals how fear and destruction surround the wicked, affirming the certainty of God's justice and the consequences of sin, which encourages believers to live righteously.

questions.question: What does Job 18:14-15 teach about the consequences of losing confidence and hope in God's protection?
options: Confidence will be uprooted, and the wicked will dwell with the king of terrors.
Confidence will protect the wicked forever.
Hope can be placed in earthly riches.
Confidence is irrelevant to spiritual well-being.
questions.correctAnswer: Confidence will be uprooted, and the wicked will dwell with the king of terrors.
questions.explanation: Job 18:14-15 illustrates that losing confidence in God leads to dwelling with death and destruction, highlighting the necessity of hope and trust in God's protection.

questions.question: In the context of family and legacy, what warning does Job 18:16-19 give about living a life apart from God?
options: The wicked’s roots dry up, branches are cut off, and they leave no lasting name or descendants.
The wicked build strong family legacies.
Separation from God has no effect on family.
The wicked are honored in their homes.
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked’s roots dry up, branches are cut off, and they leave no lasting name or descendants.
questions.explanation: Job 18:16-19 emphasizes that those who do not know God will lose their heritage and remembrance, underscoring the importance of faith for family legacy.

questions.question: A believer wonders about the impact of godless living on community reputation. What does Job 18:17-18 say about this?
options: The wicked’s remembrance perishes from the earth, and they are driven from light into darkness.
The wicked are celebrated in the streets.
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked’s remembrance perishes from the earth, and they are driven from light into darkness.
questions.explanation: Job 18:17-18 shows that godless living leads to loss of reputation and being cast out of the world’s light, teaching believers to live according to God’s ways.

questions.question: Based on Job 18:19-21, what does this passage teach about the importance of spiritual inheritance for future generations?
options: The wicked have no children or relatives to carry on their name, causing astonishment and fear.
Future generations always honor godless ancestors.
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked have no children or relatives to carry on their name, causing astonishment and fear.
questions.explanation: Job 18:19-21 highlights how the wicked leave no descendants and cause fear in those who come after, showing the importance of living a godly life to bless future generations.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 18:21, the dwellings of the wicked are described as a place for those who know God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 18:21 states that such are the dwellings of the wicked and the place of him that knoweth not God, indicating that the wicked do not know God.

questions.question: True or False: Job 18 teaches that anger is always a righteous response to suffering.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 18:4 questions Job’s anger and implies it is not justified to tear oneself in anger, teaching believers to exercise control and humility during suffering.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Job 18:6, the light in the wicked man's ________ will be dark, and his candle shall be put out with him.
questions.correctAnswer: tabernacle
questions.explanation: Job 18:6 uses the word 'tabernacle' to symbolize the wicked man’s dwelling or inner being where light is put out, illustrating the loss of guidance and hope.

questions.question: How does Job 18:7-9 teach about consequences in relation to integrity and honesty in daily life?
options: The wicked’s strength fails due to their own counsel and they are caught in snares, illustrating how dishonest actions lead to downfall.
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked’s strength fails due to their own counsel and they are caught in snares, illustrating how dishonest actions lead to downfall.
questions.explanation: Job 18:7-9 describes how the wicked are ensnared by their own actions, teaching that lack of integrity leads to personal ruin.

questions.question: What does Job 18:12-13 suggest about perseverance through trials and spiritual discipline?
options: Without spiritual discipline, strength is devoured by destruction and death.
Trials have no effect on the spiritually disciplined.
Destruction only affects the wicked after many years.
questions.correctAnswer: Without spiritual discipline, strength is devoured by destruction and death.
questions.explanation: Job 18:12-13 warns that destruction devours the strength of the wicked, teaching believers the importance of perseverance and spiritual discipline to withstand trials.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment. According to Job 18:14-15, what biblical truth about humility and contentment can be shared?
options: Confidence rooted in God prevents dwelling with the king of terrors, promoting humility and contentment.
Confidence is unrelated to spiritual well-being.
questions.correctAnswer: Confidence rooted in God prevents dwelling with the king of terrors, promoting humility and contentment.
questions.explanation: Job 18:14-15 contrasts the loss of confidence with dwelling with death, teaching that humility and trust in God foster contentment and peace.

questions.question: How does Job 18:20 encourage believers in evangelism and sharing the Gospel?
options: Those who come after the wicked are astonished and afraid of their day, showing the need to warn others through the Gospel.
Evangelism is unnecessary as all are saved.
Fear should prevent sharing the Gospel.
questions.correctAnswer: Those who come after the wicked are astonished and afraid of their day, showing the need to warn others through the Gospel.
questions.explanation: Job 18:20 highlights the fearful legacy of the wicked, encouraging believers to share the Gospel to lead others to salvation and avoid such a fate.

hard.title: Job Chapter 18 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Job Chapter 18.

questions.question: In Job 18, Bildad the Shuhite accuses the wicked of having their light put out. Which metaphor is used to describe this extinguishing of the wicked’s life?
options: The spark of his fire shall not shine
The sun is swallowed by darkness
questions.correctAnswer: The spark of his fire shall not shine
questions.explanation: Job 18:5 uses the metaphor of a spark of fire that shall not shine to describe the extinguishing of the wicked’s light, symbolizing the end of their life and strength.

questions.question: Bildad asks, “Shall the earth be forsaken for thee?” What literary device is primarily used in this rhetorical question?
questions.correctAnswer: Rhetorical question
questions.explanation: In Job 18:4, Bildad uses a rhetorical question to emphasize the idea that the earth and rock will not move or be forsaken for Job, highlighting human insignificance.

questions.question: What phrase in Job 18:14 signifies a transition into death imagery and is a poetic personification of death itself?
questions.correctAnswer: The king of terrors
questions.explanation: Job 18:14 uses the phrase 'king of terrors' to personify death, a common ancient Near Eastern motif representing death’s power and fearfulness.

questions.question: According to Bildad in Job 18, what will happen to the wicked’s 'roots' and 'branch'?
options: His roots shall be dried up beneath, and above shall his branch be cut off
His roots shall grow deep, and his branch be strong
His roots shall be scattered, and his branch shall flourish
His roots shall be watered, and his branch shall blossom
questions.correctAnswer: His roots shall be dried up beneath, and above shall his branch be cut off
questions.explanation: Job 18:16 describes the destruction of the wicked’s lineage and stability using the imagery of roots drying and branches being cut off, symbolizing total ruin.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'His confidence shall be rooted out of his ____, and it shall bring him to the king of terrors.'
questions.correctAnswer: tabernacle
questions.explanation: Job 18:14 states that the wicked’s confidence will be rooted out of his 'tabernacle,' which poetically represents his dwelling or inner self.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the overall theme of Bildad's speech in Job 18?
options: The inevitable destruction and ruin of the wicked
The hope of redemption for the afflicted
questions.correctAnswer: The inevitable destruction and ruin of the wicked
questions.explanation: Job 18 is primarily a discourse by Bildad emphasizing the downfall and destruction awaiting the wicked as a result of their actions.

questions.question: Bildad uses the imagery of traps and snares in Job 18. What is the purpose of this imagery?
options: To illustrate how the wicked are ensnared by their own actions
To depict the hunting of animals in ancient Near East
To warn against literal physical traps in the wilderness
To describe the dangers of enemies attacking Israel
questions.correctAnswer: To illustrate how the wicked are ensnared by their own actions
questions.explanation: Verses 8-10 describe the wicked as caught in nets and snares, symbolizing the consequences of their own deeds entangling them in ruin.

questions.question: In the context of Job 18, what does Bildad mean by saying 'They that come after him shall be astonied at his day, as they that went before were affrighted'?
options: The wicked’s downfall will cause fear and astonishment across generations
The wicked will be celebrated by future generations
The wicked’s legacy will be a source of wisdom
The wicked will be forgotten immediately after death
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked’s downfall will cause fear and astonishment across generations
questions.explanation: Job 18:20 highlights that the day of the wicked’s destruction will be marked with terror and awe by both past and future generations.

questions.question: True or False: Bildad concludes in Job 18 that the dwellings of the wicked are places of blessing and divine favor.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 18:21 clearly states that the dwellings of the wicked are places of condemnation, described as the place of him that knows not God.

questions.question: Which phrase in Job 18 reflects the ancient Near Eastern belief about the permanence of a person's name and memory?
options: His remembrance shall perish from the earth, and he shall have no name in the street
The earth shall tremble at his feet
His name shall be carved on stones forever
His memory shall be celebrated by the nations
questions.correctAnswer: His remembrance shall perish from the earth, and he shall have no name in the street
questions.explanation: Job 18:17 communicates that the wicked’s legacy and memory will be completely erased, which contrasts with the cultural importance of preserving one’s name and honor.

questions.question: Bildad uses the imagery of light and darkness multiple times. How does this reflect a broader biblical motif?
options: Light symbolizes life and blessing, while darkness symbolizes death and judgment
Light and darkness represent day and night cycles
Light is a metaphor for wealth, darkness for poverty
Light and darkness refer to seasonal changes
questions.correctAnswer: Light symbolizes life and blessing, while darkness symbolizes death and judgment
questions.explanation: In Job 18:6 and 18:18, light and darkness symbolize the contrast between the presence of life and divine favor versus death and divine judgment, a common biblical motif.

questions.question: What is the significance of Bildad calling Job and his friends 'beasts' and 'vile' in Job 18:3?
options: It reflects a rhetorical strategy to shame Job and question his wisdom
It is a compliment reflecting their humility
It praises their closeness to nature
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects a rhetorical strategy to shame Job and question his wisdom
questions.explanation: Job 18:3’s harsh wording is a rhetorical device meant to belittle Job’s arguments and assert Bildad’s position that Job’s complaints are unworthy.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'His strength shall be ______, and destruction shall be ready at his side.'
questions.correctAnswer: hungerbitten
questions.explanation: Job 18:12 states that the wicked’s strength is 'hungerbitten,' emphasizing a wasting away or weakening leading to destruction.

questions.question: How does the structure of Bildad’s speech in Job 18 reflect ancient Hebrew poetic parallelism?
options: Pairs of lines that echo and intensify the message about the fate of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: Pairs of lines that echo and intensify the message about the fate of the wicked
questions.explanation: Job 18 exhibits synonymous and synthetic parallelism, a hallmark of Hebrew poetry, where ideas about the wicked’s ruin are repeated and amplified in paired lines.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage most directly contrasts with Bildad's portrayal of retributive justice in Job 18 by emphasizing God's grace over judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Romans 5:8
questions.explanation: Romans 5:8 highlights God's love demonstrated through Christ’s sacrifice while we were sinners, contrasting Bildad’s retributive justice theme in Job 18.

theological.title: Job Chapter 18 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Job Chapter 18 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Bildad in Job 18, what happens to the light of the wicked?
options: It shines brighter than the sun
It becomes a guiding flame for others
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be put out
questions.explanation: Bildad states in Job 18:5 that 'the light of the wicked shall be put out,' indicating the extinguishing of their influence and life. This is consistent with Proverbs 4:19, Psalm 37:20, John 3:19, and 2 Thessalonians 1:9, which describe the fate of the wicked as darkness or destruction.

questions.question: What does Bildad say about the dwelling of the wicked in Job 18?
options: It shall be full of light and joy
It is the place of him that knoweth not God
It is a place of refuge
questions.correctAnswer: It is the place of him that knoweth not God
questions.explanation: In Job 18:21, Bildad describes the dwelling of the wicked as 'the place of him that knoweth not God.' This aligns with biblical teaching that separation from God leads to destruction (Psalm 1:4-6, Isaiah 59:2, 1 Corinthians 2:14, and Hebrews 10:31).

questions.question: What imagery does Bildad use to describe the fate of the wicked's strength?
options: It shall be strengthened and exalted
It shall be devoured by the firstborn of death
It shall be hidden under a rock
It shall be renewed like the eagle's
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be devoured by the firstborn of death
questions.explanation: Job 18:13 says 'even the firstborn of death shall devour his strength,' depicting death as a consuming force. This imagery is echoed in Psalm 49:15, Ezekiel 18:4, Hebrews 9:27, and Revelation 20:14 showing death's finality and power over the wicked.

questions.question: What consequence is described for the wicked in Job 18 regarding their remembrance and name?
options: Their memory shall perish from the earth and they shall have no name in the street
They shall be honored among their people
They shall be exalted in the assembly
questions.correctAnswer: Their memory shall perish from the earth and they shall have no name in the street
questions.explanation: Job 18:17 states that the wicked's remembrance will perish and they will have no name, symbolizing ultimate disgrace and oblivion. This is consistent with Psalm 37:36, Proverbs 10:7, Isaiah 26:14, and Matthew 7:23 which speak of the fate of the ungodly as being forgotten or cut off.

questions.question: How does Bildad describe the security of the wicked's steps in Job 18?
options: Their steps are firm and sure
Their steps shall be straitened and their own counsel shall cast them down
They shall walk on the heights without fear
They shall be guided by angels
questions.correctAnswer: Their steps shall be straitened and their own counsel shall cast them down
questions.explanation: Job 18:7 explains that the wicked's strength is limited and their own plans lead to their downfall. This matches Proverbs 14:12, Psalm 1:6, Jeremiah 10:23, and James 1:14-15, which warn of self-deception and destruction resulting from sinful counsel.

questions.question: Bildad uses the metaphor of a snare to describe the wicked's predicament. What does he say about this snare?
options: The snare will be broken by the wicked
The snare is laid for the wicked in the ground and a trap in the way
The snare is a symbol of God's grace
questions.correctAnswer: The snare is laid for the wicked in the ground and a trap in the way
questions.explanation: Job 18:10 describes the snare and trap as set for the wicked, symbolizing inevitable judgment. Similar imagery is found in Psalm 91:3, Proverbs 29:6, Isaiah 59:5, and 2 Timothy 3:13, which speak of traps and snares for the wicked.

questions.question: What does Bildad say about the family legacy of the wicked in Job 18?
options: They shall neither have son nor nephew among his people
Their lineage shall be established forever
Their children will be kings and priests
questions.correctAnswer: They shall neither have son nor nephew among his people
questions.explanation: Job 18:19 indicates that the wicked will have no surviving descendants, emphasizing total loss of legacy. This aligns with Psalm 37:25, Malachi 4:6, Isaiah 14:20, and Luke 1:17, which explain the judgment of God extending sometimes to the family line of the wicked.

questions.question: In Job 18, Bildad challenges Job’s speech by asking how long he will continue in what?
questions.correctAnswer: Words without end
questions.explanation: Job 18:2 says 'How long will it be ere ye make an end of words?' indicating Bildad's frustration with Job's lengthy complaints. This reflects the biblical theme of wearying God with endless complaints (Psalm 13:1-2, Ecclesiastes 5:2, Isaiah 29:13, and Philippians 2:14).

questions.question: What does Bildad accuse Job of that causes others to count them as beasts and vile?
questions.correctAnswer: Because of Job’s words
questions.explanation: Job 18:3 states, 'Wherefore are we counted as beasts, and reputed vile in your sight?' in response to Job's harsh words. This shows how speech can affect reputation, consistent with Proverbs 18:21, James 3:6, Psalm 12:3, and Ephesians 4:29.

questions.question: What does Bildad say about the roots and branches of the wicked in Job 18?
options: The roots shall flourish and branches grow
The roots shall be dried up and the branch cut off
The roots shall be deep and branches fruitful
The roots shall be watered and branches green
questions.correctAnswer: The roots shall be dried up and the branch cut off
questions.explanation: Job 18:16 uses the metaphor of a tree to describe the wicked’s destruction. This is consistent with Psalm 1:3, Jeremiah 17:5, Matthew 7:19, and John 15:6, illustrating that those who do not abide in God are cut off and wither.

questions.question: According to Job 18, how does Bildad depict the wicked’s final dwelling?
options: A place of peace and rest
questions.correctAnswer: A habitation scattered with brimstone
questions.explanation: Job 18:15 says 'brimstone shall be scattered upon his habitation,' symbolizing divine judgment and destruction, similar to the fate of Sodom and Gomorrah (Genesis 19:24, Isaiah 34:9-10, Revelation 21:8, and 2 Peter 2:6).

questions.question: What does Bildad assert about the wicked’s confidence in Job 18?
options: Their confidence shall be rooted out of their tabernacle
questions.correctAnswer: Their confidence shall be rooted out of their tabernacle
questions.explanation: Job 18:14 declares that the wicked lose their confidence, which may symbolize hope or security. This aligns with Isaiah 10:20-22, Psalm 27:3, Jeremiah 17:7-8, and Hebrews 3:13 about the downfall of the wicked’s assurance.

questions.question: How does Bildad describe the wicked’s experience of fear in Job 18?
options: Terrors shall make them afraid on every side
They trust in their own strength
They find peace in their wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Terrors shall make them afraid on every side
questions.explanation: Job 18:11 states that terrors surround the wicked, causing fear. This corresponds with Psalm 91:5-6, Isaiah 51:7, John 16:33, and 1 Peter 5:8, which acknowledge that fear and terror are consequences of separation from God.

questions.question: What does Bildad say about the wicked's destruction and hunger in Job 18?
options: Their strength shall be hungerbitten and destruction ready at their side
They shall be nourished by God’s hand
questions.correctAnswer: Their strength shall be hungerbitten and destruction ready at their side
questions.explanation: Job 18:12 indicates the wicked's strength is consumed by hunger and destruction. This reflects Proverbs 28:27, Isaiah 33:16, Matthew 25:35, and Revelation 6:8, highlighting the judgment and ruin awaiting the wicked.

questions.question: According to Job 18, what is Bildad’s view on the earth and rock in relation to Job’s anger?
options: The earth shall be forsaken for Job
The rock shall be removed for Job
The earth and rock remain unmoved despite Job's anger
The earth and rock tremble at Job’s words
questions.correctAnswer: The earth and rock remain unmoved despite Job's anger
questions.explanation: Job 18:4 says, 'shall the earth be forsaken for thee? and shall the rock be removed out of his place?' meaning God’s creation remains stable despite Job’s anger. This aligns with Psalm 104:5, Isaiah 54:10, Hebrews 1:10-12, and Revelation 21:1, affirming God’s unchanging sovereignty.
